intro: Rhus angolensis, commonly known as the African sumac, is a deciduous shrub or small tree native to southern Africa. It belongs to the Anacardiaceae family, which includes other well-known plants like the cashew and poison ivy. The plant is characterized by its compound leaves, which are typically pinnately arranged with serrated edges. It produces small, yellowish-green flowers followed by red, fuzzy fruits that contain several seeds. Rhus angolensis is often found in rocky or sandy soils and is adapted to arid or semi-arid environments.
